There has been a considerable amount of correspondence on this subject, and I have recently advocated the appointment of Royal Air Force chaplains at Aden and its separation from the Diocese of Bombay. My reason for departing from the recommendation made in my letter of the 10th August 1933 that Aden should remain in the Diocese of Bombay and continue to be served by chaplains of the Indian Ecclesiastical Establishment was that I was given to understand that it would be impossible to send these Indian Service chaplains to Aden after the transfer except on a voluntary basis, which, in my opinion, would be unworkable. I have, however, now heard from the Bishop of Bombay that he hopes to find a means of overcoming this difficulty. If so, I would gladly revert to my original view that the present ecclesiastical arrangements should continue. This opinion is, however, subject to one reservation. At present the normal establishment here is two chaplains, of whom one is paid wholly by the Government of India and the other is paid in the proportion of one- quarter^ by the Government of India and three-quarters by the Air Ministry. As at least three-quarters of the members of the Church of England in Aden belong to the Amny and Royal Air Force I consider that the Air Ministry ought to pay three-quarters of the total cost of the ecclesiastical establishment. I understand that they are willing to do so for one chaplain but are not prepared to pay any part of the cost of a second chaplain. I do not consider that Aden revenues can justifiably be debited with one and one-quarter of the cost of the chaplains who are here mainly for the benefit of His Majesty*s Services, and if the Air Ministry are not prepared to modify their view the establishment ^Ji\will have to he reduced from two chaplains to one. In my opinion this would be an undesirable result as I do not think that one chaplain is sufficient, and the absence of a second chaplain leaves no provision for sickness or short leaves of absence. If it is eventually decided to increase the permanent garrison of Aden, I hope that the Air Ministry will modify their view and will agree to bear a proportionate share of the cost of two chaplains. At present the Air Ministry pay an annual contribution of Rs.450 in respect of the maintenance of Churches and Rs.450 for the maintenance of cemeteries. I recommend that these contributions should continue to be made.Mr. laithwaite. As a result of the dissolution of the legal union between the Church of Hhgland and the Church of Sngland in India, any question relating to the extent or limits of the diocese of Bombay is for the General Council of the Church , and Government appears to have no authority in the matter. It is unlikely, however, that the Church would exclude Aden from the diocese of Bombay as a consequence of any political changes separating Aden from India. At present the Government of India provides chaplains from the Bombay Cadre of the Indian Ecclesiastical Establishment for two civil chaplaincies at Aden. The cost to India is reduced by an annual contribution made by the i 1 Air Ministry in respect of religious ministrations h to the Church of England members of the garrison. The correspondence on the subject of that contribution is in the Military Department, and from its volume, it would appear that thearrangement has not proved entirely satisfactory either to the Air 1 inistry or to the Government of India. If Aden is separated from India, the Government of India may prefer that the Aden authorities should obtain their own chaplains. The fact that the Bishop of Bombay exercises authority in Aden is not necessarily any obstacle to an arrangement of that kind which might prove economical since,in addition to the chaplains salaries^ the payments that would have to be made to the Government of India in respect of leave and pension contributions for the 2 chaplains lent to Aden would be considerable. titleInfo.title: Coll 1/41 'Aden. Changes in civil administration in the event of separation from India: ecclesiastical; to remain part of diocese of Bombay'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in rough chronological order from the rear to the front of the file

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 12; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence between the Aden Chief Commissioner (Bernard Reilly), the India Office, and the Colonial Office, regarding the possibility of Aden remaining part of the Diocese of Bombay upon transfer to Colonial Office administration. Chaplaincy arrangements are discussed.
